title: refutable f64 pattern in function argument

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-patterns
labels.description: Relating to patterns and pattern matching

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
const x: f64 = 0.0;

fn foo(x: f64) {
}
fn main(){   
}
```

I expected it to compile and instead i get the following error message:

```
Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
warning: floating-point types cannot be used in patterns
 --> src/main.rs:5:8
  |
5 | fn foo(x: f64) {
  |        ^
  |
  = warning: this was previously accepted by the compiler but is being phased out; it will become a hard error in a future release!
  = note: for more information, [see issue #41620 <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/41620>](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/41620)
  = note: `#[warn(illegal_floating_point_literal_pattern)]` on by default

error[[E0005]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/error-index.html#E0005): refutable pattern in function argument: `_` not covered
 --> src/main.rs:5:8
  |
3 | const x: f64 = 0.0;
  | ------------ constant defined here
4 |
5 | fn foo(x: f64) {
  |        ^
  |        |
  |        interpreted as a constant pattern, not a new variable
  |        help: introduce a variable instead: `x_var`
  |
  = note: the matched value is of type `f64`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0005`.
```

i don't think it is right that a global const declaration can invalidate some possible arguments names in function declarations.
